PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN STOCK NEWS: ANZ officially puts life insurance business up for sale; Takata to be acquired and rebranded; WTI crude rose 2% amid geopolitical concerns
content:
AUSTRALIA

ANZ Bank (ANZ AT)
- Co. officially placed its New Zealand life insurance business for sale. (AFR)

Brambles (BXB AT)
- Co. reaches agreement to divest 50% stake in Hoover Ferguson JV in deal valued at AUD 150mln. (Newswires)

Healthscope (HSO AT)
- BGH Capital and Bain Capital are said to be interested in the Co. (The Australian)

Infigen Energy (IFN AT)
- Brookfield discloses a stake of over 9% in the Co. (Newswires)

Westpac (WBC AT)
- Co. is to include disclosure of mortgage applicants’ spending habits as part of new application requirement. (AFR)

Infrastructure
- Australian government is to contribute AUD 5.0bln on Melbourne airport rail network. (Newswires)

Retailers
- Woolworths (WOW AT), Wesfarmers (WES AT) Coles unit and Metcash (MTS AT) will face additional competition next year when Germany’s Kaufland enters the Australian market. (AFR)

Other News
- The major Australian annual showcase of trade and business in China looks set to be abandoned this year, amid a cooling of ties between Australia and China. (AFR)

Basic Materials / Energy
- Spot gold rose 0.8% and iron ore fell 0.8%.
- WTI crude futures increased over 2% to briefly above USD 67/bbl. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Aeon (8267 JT)
- Co. FY17/18 net JPY 24.5bln vs. Prev. JPY 11.3bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Aeon Mall (8905 JT)
- Co. FY 17/18 net JPY 30.5bln vs. Prev. JPY 28.5bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Lawson (2651 JT)
- Co. FY17/18 net JPY 26.8bln vs. Prev. JPY 36.4bln Y/Y, rev. JPY 657bln vs. Prev. JPY 631bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Takata (7312 JT)
- Co. is to be acquired by Joyson & Pag fund KSS for USD 1.59bln and will be rebranded as Joyson Safety Systems. (Newswires)

Travel
- Japan approved departure tax of JPY 1000 per person effective in 2019. (Newswires)

Other News
- Japan’s ruling coalition will allow former PM Abe aide to be questioned on allegations he intervened to win approval for a veterinary school project linked to a friend of PM Abe. (Nikkei)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS)
- Co. posted its first rise in China sales in 15-months with its March car sales up 34.8% Y/Y to 97,100 units. (Newswires)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS)
- Co. partners with Sempio to expand into built-in kitchen appliance market. (Newswires)
- Prosecutors have called in labor union officials of a Co. unit as part of investigation the Co. attempted to sabotage establishments of trade unions in its affiliates. (Newswires)

Samsung Securities (016360 KS)
- Co. said it will compensate shareholders who sold shares in the wake of the dividend payment error. (Yonhap)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
FOMC MINUTES

FOMC minutes stated that further policy tightening likely warranted and almost all agreed a gradual approach was appropriate, while several said future Fed’s Fund Rate will likely need to be above its longer-run normal value for a time.

All expected 1-year inflation to rise in coming month but noted the increase would not by itself justify a change in projected path, while many policymakers said they were confident that inflation would rise to target and stabilise around that level.

All policymakers agreed that economic outlook has improved in the recent months, while a number of policymakers said economic outlook implies steeper rise in Fed funds rate over the next few years than previously expected.

Some policymakers said future fed statements may need to signal that policy will shift to a neutral or restraining factor for the economy, while a majority of policymakers view the retaliatory tariffs by other countries a downside risk for US.

There was little by way of an immediate reaction, however, as the dust settled, traders latched-on to the more hawkish headlines, specifically, “several” policy makers arguing that the future fed’s fund rate will likely need to be above its longer-run normal value for a time, and also future FOMC statements may need to signal that policy will shift to a neutral or restraining factor for the economy. The USD moved towards session highs against the EUR, with EUR/USD falling from 1.2370 to around 1.2350 and USDJPY rose above 107.00 from around 106.85, while moves along the Treasury curve were more muted, though the bias was for slightly higher yields.
 

ASIA-PAC

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said China has previously made promises and not delivered, although he added that President Xi's speech is a positive development. (Newswires)
 

UK

UK NIESR GDP Q1 growth estimate at +0.2% quarter on quarter vs. +0.4% for Q4, with the main reason due to March weather. (Newswires)

UK Industrial Output (Feb) M/M 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.40% (Prev. 1.30%). (Newswires)
UK Industrial Output (Feb) Y/Y 2.20% vs. Exp. 2.90% (Prev. 1.60%, Rev. 1.20%)
UK Manufacturing Output (Feb) M/M -0.20% vs. Exp. 0.20% (Prev. 0.10%, Rev. 0.00%)
UK Manufacturing Output (Feb) Y/Y 2.50% vs. Exp. 3.30% (Prev. 2.70%, Rev. 2.20%)
UK Construction Output Vol (Feb) M/M -1.6% vs. Exp. 0.70% (Prev. -3.40%, Rev. -3.1%)
UK Construction Output Vol (Feb) Y/Y -3.0% vs. Exp. -2.50% (Prev. -3.90%, Rev. -2.1%)
UK Goods Trade Balance (GBP)(Feb) -10.20B vs. Exp. -12B (Prev. -12.33B, Rev. -12.23B)

EU

ECB's Draghi (Dovish) is confident inflation will rise to ECB's goal and added that wages and inflation will rise as economy improves. (Newswires)

ECB’s Hansson (Hawk) said recent euro area economy improvements will accelerate inflation and that the ECB has to be more patient in achieving its goal, while Hansson added that ECB has less and less policy space but that It is not exhausted. (Newswires)


FX

The JPY caught a slight bid on geopolitical concerns, although some had noted that the CHF remained soft (trite whispers of SNB intervention did the rounds). The buck was generally softer, with the weakness today being framed as uncertainty around US military action, keeping DXY near the 89.50 area; there was also some caution ahead of US CPI and FOMC meeting minutes – both of which failed to provide any meaningful price action, though the latter helped inject a slight bullish note. The EUR range was narrow, between c.1.2350 and just under 1.24, with offers around the latter preventing a meaningful test. The strength in crude prices helped push USDCAD lower and penetrating 1.2550 briefly. AUD and NZD were lower, in line with risk sentiment. The RUB and TRY – both supposed proxies for using FX to express Syria trades – were both lower, with the Lira printing another record low against the dollar.


COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks (6 Mar) 3.036M vs. Exp. -0.189M (Prev. -4.617M); crude production rose 0.62% to 10.525mln bpd. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump stated that missiles will be coming on Syria, while he also stated that relationship with Russia is now worse than it has ever been. Furthermore, Trump noted that all nations to work together and suggested to stop the arms race. (Twitter)

Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman said “smart missiles should fly towards terrorists, not legal government” and “great idea, let’s start with US chemical weapons” in response to Trump’s tweets. (Newswires)

White House said that US President Trump holds Russia and Syria responsible for the Syria chemical attack, while there were also reports that US President Trump is to make a decision on Syria tonight. (Newswires / 24live)

UK is moving submarines within range of Syria for strikes which could begin as soon as Thursday night, although reports added that UK PM May has not yet reached a final decision on whether to join any airstrikes. (Telegraph) In addition, the cabinet will meet on Thursday and UK PM May is expected to ask approval for UK participation in action against Syrian chemical weapons infrastructure. (Sky News)

The Syrian observatory said the pro-Syrian government forces have emptied main airports and military bases over possible US action. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia coalition said to have struck Sana’a International Airport in Yemen. (Maseera TV)


US

US House Speaker Ryan is said to announce he is not running again. (Axios)

NAFTA officials are to meet this week to accelerate a push for a preliminary agreement, according to sources. (Newswires)

US CPI (Mar) M/M -0.10% vs. Exp. 0.00% (Prev. 0.20%). (Newswires)
US CPI (Mar) Y/Y 2.40% vs. Exp. 2.40% (Prev. 2.20%)
US Core CPI (Mar) M/M 0.20% vs. Exp. 0.20% (Prev. 0.20%)
US Core CPI (Mar) Y/Y 2.10% vs. Exp. 2.10% (Prev. 1.80%)
US Real Weekly Earnings MM (Mar) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.20% (Prev. 0.30%)


MARKET RECAP

A quiet overnight session was shaken to life after US President Trump’s pre-market tweeting, where he talked-up the possibility of military action in the Middle East, sending futures sharply lower. As trade progressed, there was a rebound, however, and the Emini turned slightly positive until the hawkish tone of the FOMC meeting minutes led to negative ticks in the Emini, before once again basing around the almost magnetic 2,650 level, before dipping into the close. In stock specifics, toymaker Mattel (MAT) led the NDX in Wednesday trade following an upgrade from Jefferies. On the flipside of the NDX, Fastenal (FAST) was the largest laggard following its Q1 earnings report (mostly in line), but it noted its gross profit did fell and net sales were also down. FAST was also the laggard of the S&P. On the positive side, SPX gains were led by Hilton Worldwide (HLT) following a secondary stock offering at $73/shr, and reports that HNA China is selling the shares and that the proceeds from the sale will not be received by the hotel business. Exxon (XOM) led the DJI tracking crude prices higher, but Boeing (BA) a laggard - energy was the only green sector on Wednesday. Telecoms, meanwhile, underperformed. M&A news was light, but CBC (CBS) and Viacom (VIAB) took the limelight again after CNBC’s Faber noted the former is expected to make another offer soon for the latter, but the new bid will likely be insufficient; pre-market reports also suggested Shari Redstone is considering a merger with or without CBS CEO Moonves. Separately, Analogic (ALOG) is going to be purchased by PE firm Altaris Capital Partners for USD 84/shr, significantly lower than the closing price on Tuesday of $96.05. SPX -0.55% at 2642, NDX -0.49% at 6583 , DJI -0.90% at 24189.

In spite of geopolitical risks spooking traders, lending a bid to some haven assets, the Treasury complex was only slightly higher on the day, with the curve modestly bull-flattening, and major curve spreads narrowed once again (5s30s at 38bps now, while 2s30s slipped by nearly 3bps to 68bps). There was some knee-jerk buying of Treasuries as US President Trump ramped-up the rhetoric, telling Russia to ‘expect missiles’ in Syria, and the buying pushed 30-year yields to beneath the 3.00% handle, while 10s visited 2.75%. The Treasury’s 10-year auction was soft, seeing a tail of 0.5bps (recent averages suggested it would come in on the screws).  The internals were grim, with indirect participation the lowest since January 2015, leaving directs and dealers with participation above recent averages. The soft auction had surprised a few analysts, particularly amid demand for haven assets today, as the US prepares military action in Syria. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 2+ ticks higher at 120-27.

subject: US President Trump holds Russia and Syria responsible for the Syria chemical attack; according to the White House
US MARKET WRAP 11 April 2018: Markets on edge as US prepares potential military action in the middle east
content:
* SNAPSHOT: Stocks lower, USD flat, treasuries higher, oil higher
* REAR-VIEW: Geopolitical tensions rise, Hawkish FOMC Minutes, US CPI in-line
* AHEAD: Trump decision on Syria, Asia C-bank speak, Earnings season gets underway

* GEOPOLITICS: Following Russia’s warning that US military action in Syria over alleged use of chemical weapons will be met with Russian assistance to Syria, US President Trump upped the rhetoric, warning Russia to “get ready” for missiles. There were further reports on Wednesday that pro-government forces in Syria had begun evacuating airports and military basis in preparation for US strikes. US defence secretary Mattis said the US is assessing intelligence on Syrian chemical attack, and the military stands ready to provide options upon the order from President Trump. Meanwhile, a Russian official said that Moscow and US militaries were in contact over Syria. Later reports suggested that President Trump will make a decision on Syria on Wednesday evening.

* TRADE WARS: News flow was quiet on Wednesday, partly because the market’s attention has been fixed on geopolitics. Trump will be meeting members of Congress tomorrow to discuss tariffs. Elsewhere, traders are on the look-out for the US Treasury’s semi-annual currency report, which is set to be released ‘mid-April’. Attention will be on whether the US labels China a currency manipulator, or not. The move might be seen as a belligerent escalation, and instead, some are of the opinion that, ahead of midterms, the US may make an example out of other nations – perhaps India or Thailand – to demonstrate it is taking action against alleged currency manipulation.

* US CPI MM (Mar) -0.10% (Exp. 0.00%, Prev. 0.20%); US CPI YY (Mar) 2.40% (Exp. 2.40%, Prev. 2.20%). US headline CPI increased to 2.4% YY, as anticipated, from 2.2%, largely on base effects led by cell phone price plans adding 0.2ppts alone to the figure. The core measure rose to 2.1% YY in line with estimates, above 2.0% for the first time since March 2017. The gains were in part offset by lower apparel and used car prices, which fell by 0.3%. The core measure was also lifted by higher medical care prices. Nonetheless, the recent 5% decline in oil prices pushed the MM figure into negative territory at -0.1%. Analysts have said that the firmer than expected PPI prints as well as the solid CPI data will likely keep the Fed firmly on track for another 25bps rate hike in June. There was little market reaction.

* FOMC MEETING MINUTES: Although the March meeting minutes contained few major surprises, the tone was hawkish, while traders also noted that the central bank was more confident in the medium-term trajectory for inflation. Q1 growth weakness is seen as transitory. While the FOMC reiterated gradual hikes, the kicker was the line that “several participants expressed the judgment that it would likely become appropriate at some point for the Committee to set the federal funds rate above its longer run normal value for a time” which traders cited for a (delayed) hawkish market reaction (which saw USD strength, though Treasuries were more inert). Additionally, some policymakers said future Fed statements may need to signal that policy will shift to a neutral or restraining factor for the economy, adding further hawkish overtones.

* EQUITIES: SPX -0.55% at 2642, NDX -0.49% at 6583 , DJI -0.90% at 24189 SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): -0.32%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): -0.21%, ENERGY (XLE): +1.04%, FINANCIALS (XLF): -1.26%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): -0.86%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): -0.75%, MATERIALS (XLB): -0.78%, TECH (XLK): -0.51%, TELECOMS (XTL): -1.49%, UTLITIES (XLU): -0.15%.   A quiet overnight session was shaken to life after US President Trump’s pre-market tweeting, where he talked-up the possibility of military action in the Middle East, sending futures sharply lower. As trade progressed, there was a rebound, however, and the Emini turned slightly positive until the hawkish tone of the FOMC meeting minutes led to negative ticks in the Emini, before once again basing around the almost magnetic 2,650 level, before dipping into the close. In stock specifics, toymaker Mattel (MAT) led the NDX in Wednesday trade following an upgrade from Jefferies. On the flipside of the NDX, Fastenal (FAST) was the largest laggard following its Q1 earnings report (mostly in line), but it noted its gross profit did fell and net sales were also down. FAST was also the laggard of the S&P. On the positive side, SPX gains were led by Hilton Worldwide (HLT) following a secondary stock offering at $73/shr, and reports that HNA China is selling the shares and that the proceeds from the sale will not be received by the hotel business. Exxon (XOM) led the DJI tracking crude prices higher, but Boeing (BA) a laggard - energy was the only green sector on Wednesday. Telecoms, meanwhile, underperformed. M&A news was light, but CBC (CBS) and Viacom (VIAB) took the limelight again after CNBC’s Faber noted the former is expected to make another offer soon for the latter, but the new bid will likely be insufficient; pre-market reports also suggested Shari Redstone is considering a merger with or without CBS CEO Moonves. Separately, Analogic (ALOG) is going to be purchased by PE firm Altaris Capital Partners for USD 84/shr, significantly lower than the closing price on Tuesday of $96.05.

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futs settled 2+ ticks higher at 120-27. In spite of geopolitical risks spooking traders, lending a bid to some haven assets, the Treasury complex was only slightly higher on the day, with the curve modestly bull-flattening, and major curve spreads narrowed once again (5s30s at 38bps now, while 2s30s slipped by nearly 3bps to 68bps). There was some knee-jerk buying of Treasuries as US President Trump ramped-up the rhetoric, telling Russia to ‘expect missiles’ in Syria, and the buying pushed 30-year yields to beneath the 3.00% handle, while 10s visited 2.75%. The Treasury’s 10-year auction was soft, seeing a tail of 0.5bps (recent averages suggested it would come in on the screws).  The internals were grim, with indirect participation the lowest since January 2015, leaving directs and dealers with participation above recent averages. The soft auction had surprised a few analysts, particularly amid demand for haven assets today, as the US prepares military action in Syria.

* CRUDE: WTI (May) settles $1.31 higher at $66.82; Brent (June) settles $1.02 higher at $72.06. Oil rose to the highest since 2014, underpinned by increasing geopolitical tensions raising risks of supply disruptions in the Middle East, while sanctions on Russia are also supporting the complex, and additionally, Trump has just over one month (12 May deadline) to decide whether or not to reapply sanctions on Iran, or not, bringing together a collection of bullish factors for crude. There is also optimism that the OPEC and IEA reports, due Friday, will take a bullish tone as the EIA STEO did on Monday (2018 supply growth cut, 2019 supply growth estimated raised; 2018 demand view raised, as was 2019). Traders looked through the weekly DOE inventory data (crude stocks +3.036M vs. exp. -0.189M, Cushing +1.129mln vs. exp +1.5mln, distillate -1.044mln vs. exp -0.029mln, gasoline +0.458mln vs exp -1.425mln; crude production rose 0.62% to 10.525mln bpd), which was slightly more bearish than the API report on Tuesday.

* FOREX: The JPY caught a slight bid on geopolitical concerns, although some had noted that the CHF remained soft (trite whispers of SNB intervention did the rounds). The buck was generally softer, with the weakness today being framed as uncertainty around US military action, keeping DXY near the 89.50 area; there was also some caution ahead of US CPI and FOMC meeting minutes – both of which failed to provide any meaningful price action, though the latter helped inject a slight bullish note. The EUR range was narrow, between c.1.2350 and just under 1.24, with offers around the latter preventing a meaningful test. The strength in crude prices helped push USDCAD lower and penetrating 1.2550 briefly. AUD and NZD were lower, in line with risk sentiment. The RUB and TRY – both supposed proxies for using FX to express Syria trades – were both lower, with the Lira printing another record low against the dollar.

The buck was generally softer, with the weakness today being framed as uncertainty around US military action, keeping DXY near the 89.50 area; there was also some caution ahead of US CPI and FOMC meeting minutes – both of which failed to provide any meaningful price action, though the latter helped inject a slight bullish note. The EUR range was narrow, between c.1.2350 and just under 1.24, with offers around the latter preventing a meaningful test. The strength in crude prices helped push USDCAD lower and penetrating 1.2550 briefly. AUD and NZD were lower, in line with risk sentiment. The RUB and TRY – both supposed proxies for using FX to express Syria trades – were both lower, with the Lira printing another record low against the dollar.

subject: FOMC Minutes: Further policy tightening likely warranted, several said future feds fund rate will likely need to be above its longer-run normal value for a time
content:
• Further tightening policy likely warranted according to all policymakers and almost all agreed a gradual approach was appropriate
  • All expected 1 year inflation to rise in coming month, noting the increase would not by itself justify a change in projected path 
  • Majority of policymakers view the retaliatory tariffs by other countries a downside risk for US
  • Many policymakers said they are were confident that inflation would rise to target and stabilise around that level
  • All policymakers have agreed that economic outlook has improved in the recent months; a number of policymakers said economic outlook implies steeper rise in Fed funds rate over the next few years than previously expected
  • Several said future fed’s fund rate will likely need to be above its longer-run normal value for a time
  • Some policymakers said future fed statements may need to signal that policy will shift to a neutral or restraining factor for the economy
  • Generally saw the fiscal policy changes of economic effects as uncertain due to dearth of historical precedents
  • Almost all policymakers supported a hike at March meeting; a couple pointed to possible benefits of postponing hike
reaction_details: There was little by way of an immediate reaction, however, as the dust settled, traders latched-on to the more hawkish headlines, specifically, “several” policy makers arguing that the future fed’s fund rate will likely need to be above its longer-run normal value for a time, and also future FOMC statements may need to signal that policy will shift to a neutral or restraining factor for the economy. The USD moves towards session highs against the EUR, falling from 1.2370 to around 1.2350, USDJPY rose above 107.00 from around 106.85. Moves along the Treasury curve were more muted, though the bias was for slightly higher yields.

AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 21bln 10-year notes on Wednesday 11th April 2018 at 1800BST (1300 eastern time)
content:
The US Treasury will auction USD 62bln in 3-year notes (USD 30bln, Tuesday), 10-year bonds ($21bln, Wednesday) and 30-year bonds ($13bln, Thursday). With a total of USD 76.5bln maturing at mid-month settlement, the auction will actually pay down USD 12.5bln in the week. The previous 10 year auction was relatively uneventful as the issuance stopped on the screws and the cover was in line with 6- auction average. TD Securities say they expect a solid auction if 10s trade around 2.90-2.95%, but would expect a softer auction around 2.80%. At pixel time the 10y yield is 2.79%. Barclays note there has been a recent pick up in foreign demand and on a 3- month moving average basis, foreign demand is up 9ppts to 25%. It will be interesting to see if this trend continues amid the ongoing trade war rhetoric.

content:
DXY

Broadly in line US CPI data and pre-FOMC minutes positioning seem to be keeping the index afloat amidst calmer US-China trade waters, but the Dollar is still somewhat split vs major counterparts and off recent peaks against EM currencies that have been on the run. Overall risk-averse sentiment has been stoked by President Trump’s pretty clear warning about military retaliation against Syria, as the countdown to his 24-48 hour deadline approaches. Hence, safer-havens are back in demand with US-Russia relations also more strained following plenty of verbal exchanges.

JPY

Top of the G10 pile, with Usd/Jpy back to sub-107.00 levels, albeit reluctant to stray too far from big option expiry interest at the strike today and for the remainder of the week.

GBP/EUR

Tying or vying for 2nd place, with Cable reclaiming 1.4200 after a belated decline on disappointing UK data and Eur/Usd challenging offers ahead of 1.2400 despite more balanced ECB comments vs relatively hawkish Nowotny views on Tuesday – March policy meeting minutes due tomorrow.

NZD/AUD

Bucking the generally softer/consolidative trend vs the Greenback, with stops tripped on a break of  0.7350-55 leaving the Kiwi hovering near 0.7375 highs, while the cross has slipped back to the low 1.0500 area and Aud/Usd towards 0.7750 having respected resistance at 0.7785. Back to the Nzd, some relatively minor data ahead and the RBNZ on inflation targeting.

CHF

Still not behaving like a true safe-haven and flattish vs the Usd around 0.9575, while hitting new 3 year+ (ie post-1.2000 floor removal) lows vs the Eur/Chf amidst possible negative Franc M&A flows and official intervention.

EM

As noted above, the Rub and Try clawed back some heavy losses vs the Usd, latter in response to the Turkish PM signalling CB support, while the CBRT is expected to assess the situation at its April 27 policy meeting.

PRIMER: US CPI to be released at 13.30BST/08:30EDT
content:
• Analysts expect US headline CPI to rise to 2.4% YY from 2.2%, largely on base effects. The core measure is seen rising above 2.0% YY for the first time since March 2017, with the Street looking for 2.1% from 1.8%.
  • ING says the distortions and base effects will likely stem from cell phone data pricing falling out of the annual comparison, and adds that “while this may sound slightly bizarre, a quality adjustment to the CPI basket made in March last year resulted in a sharp one-off drop in communication costs and this has been knocking 0.2-0.3ppts off most core inflation measures ever since.”
  • Analysts at Capital Economics note that higher medical care prices are likely to push inflation up, even though apparel prices have ticked lower. Headline CPI MM is set to remain subdued in March following the 5% decline in oil prices. Nonetheless, any uptick in the headline is likely to place upward pressure on the YY headline, the consultancy says.

content:
11th April 2018

  • Looking ahead US CPI, DoE’s, FOMC minutes, ECB’s Hansson and ECB’s Draghi

 

TRADE WARS

PBoC Governor Yi Gang says China will implement financial market opening up steps and that China will remove foreign ownership caps on banks and China will permit domestic and foreign financial companies to compete on an equal playing field. (Newswires)

China has said they are to implement auto tariff cut as soon as possible. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed as sentiment settled down from the bullishness seen from President Xi Jinping’s conciliatory tone on Tuesday which resulted to a solid performance on Wall St, while attention turned to the geopolitical climate with a possible announcement on Syria said to be imminent. ASX 200 (-0.4%) failed to sustain mild opening gains as softer Australian consumer sentiment data and weaker than expected Chinese inflation figures clouded the upside seen in commodity related sectors. Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) was also lacklustre with J Front the worst off amongst the retailers on expectations of weaker profits this year, while SoftBank outperformed on M&A hopes after reports its unit Sprint and T-Mobile renewed merger talks. Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) were initially choppy as participants digested the miss on Chinese CPI and PPI data, although stocks gradually found some comfort from efforts by PBoC Governor Yi Gang to build upon the momentum from President Xi at the Boao forum in which the PBoC Governor talked about opening up and announced to increase stock connect quotas. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat as prices lacked direction amid an indecisive risk tone in the region, while the BoJ also kept the amounts of its Rinban announcement unchanged at just over JPY 1tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC sets CNY mid-point at 6.2911 (Prev. 6.3071). (Newswires)

PBoC skips open market operations. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

RBA Governor Lowe says board does not see a strong case for raising interest rates in the near term; more likely next move in cash rate will be up rather than down. While some central banks are hiking rates, Australian circumstances are different. Serious escalation of trade tensions would risk health of the economy. (Newswires)

BoJ Governor Kuroda says BoJ will continue powerful QE to meet inflation target, adds that there are expectations for consumer prices to keep rising. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

US-led coalition is asking all Middle East flight companies to change itinerary for next 48 hours amid possible strike, according to Kurdistan24. (Newswires)

French President Macron says chemical weapons were used in Syria and that a reaction is coming in days. (Newswires)

All Syria military bases are said to be on high alert as a US attack is expected, according to sources. (Newswires)

Yemen Houthi rebels say they have launched a drone attack at an Aramco facility in south Saudi Arabia. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

EU Chief Negotiator Barnier states that the UK still has enough time to re-evaluate the relationship it wants with the UK after Brexit, offering PM May an opportunity to move towards a closer relationship with the EU after the break-up. (Newswires)

UK Industrial Output YY (Feb) 2.20% vs. Exp. 2.90% (Prev. 1.60%, Rev. 1.20%)

UK Industrial Output MM (Feb) 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.40% (Prev. 1.30%)

EQUITIES

Equities began the day trading slightly lower (Stoxx 600 -0.2%) with the risk-on sentiment seen in yesterday’s trade not being echoed early on. This comes to fruition despite the revelations from Chinese president Xi mentioning a preference to implement auto tariff cuts as soon as possible (this relating to a possible reduction on import taxes on autos by half from 25% currently). Market sentiment is largely being guided by increased tensions in Syria amid potentially imminent military action by the US. This follows on from overnight news of increased air traffic over Syrian airspace and condemnation from the international community.  EU equity sector performance has largely been driven by company specific news with Deutsche Telekom (+4%) driving the telecoms sector higher (+0.7%) as T-Mobile, a company in which they own 64% of shares, has restarted deal talks with Sprint. Elsewhere, Tesco are seen higher (+6.2%) amid encouraging earnings, whilst Hammerson shares are seen lower (-1.9%) post the rejection of a revised proposal from Klepierre for GBP 3.65/share and finally CHR Hansen also lag their peers (-4%) amid a miss on earnings.

FX

In FX, remains narrowly mixed against G10 peers, but the Index looks prone to another downturn and test of near term chart support ahead of 89.000, with the late March low around 89.250 an obvious target. Optimism surrounding US-China trade negotiations have been somewhat neutralised or even negated by the Syrian situation. However, the Dollar could receive a reprieve from upcoming headline inflation data and or FOMC minutes. Several factors appear to have lifted GBP ahead of data with market observers still noting the bullish April seasonal element (even though the weather is still far from favourable), and of course Tuesday’s promptings from BoE hawk McCafferty. Reports suggesting an olive branch offered by chief EU Brexit negotiator Barnier may also be impacting as Cable climbed above 1.4200 and tested the next tech resistance zone 1.4215-25 (above the 10 DMA). Note, contacts reported selling in EUR/GBP from 0.8710 down to 0.8703 in the run up to the 9.30BST releases but in the event buyers were thwarted by weak output numbers vs an encouraging smaller trade shortfall. Renowned safe-havens have diverged yet again, as USD/JPY continues to hug 107.00 amidst option expiry interest at the strike, but with a more offered tone on the aforementioned geopolitical jitters. Conversely, USD/CHF is back up near 0.9600 vs circa 0.9550 at one stage, while EUR/CHF has rallied to fresh post-SNB floor removal highs around 1.1880, with M&A related flows perhaps impacting alongside more official activity, according to others. EUR is edging more gains towards 1.2400, but hampered by offers ahead of the next big figure and also wary of decent expiries between 1.2345-60 (1.8bn). ECB minutes and speeches may provide more independent direction after hawkish comments from Nowotny on Tuesday were confirmed as personal rather than a collective policy view. AUD/NZD/CAD are seeing a degree of consolidation after recent relative big moves and overall outperformance vs the US counterpart with AUD/USD meeting resistance ahead of 0.7800 (at 0.7785) after sub-forecast Chinese inflation data, a moderation in consumer sentiment and another RBA signal that rates are not going up in the near term. The Kiwi has slipped back from near 0.7375 highs to test support around 0.7350 and USD/CAD is pivoting around 1.2600. 

FIXED INCOME

Gilts got a fraction more positive momentum from the overall weakness in February factory output, or rather the lack of production in certain sectors to be precise, with a marginal and fleeting uptick. However, the core UK bond is back in range between 122.29-42 vs yesterday’s 122.25 close, with Bunds also consolidating off best levels, but retaining an underlying bid (upper end of 159.37-17 parameters vs Tuesday’s 159.05 Eurex settlement) eyeing further impetus from the impending ECB events. Technically, the 10 year German benchmark has not clearly breached the nearest upside chart resistance area from 159.30-35 that would open up pre-Nowotny levels around 159.50. Elsewhere, US Treasuries remain relatively lacklustre ahead of CPI, FOMC minutes and the 10 year auction, after a lacklustre 3 year sale to kick-off this week’s supply. On that note, Germany’s 30 year tap was not even given a lukewarm greeting by investors, but the relatively limited negative reaction in futures is testament to as degree of demand for safe-haven debt in the current fragile risk climate.

Germany sells EUR 1.043bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.5bln 2.5% 2046 Bund with a b/c 1.0 (prev. b/c 1.8), average yield 1.12% (prev. 1.29%) and retention of 30.47% (prev. 19.5%). (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent crude futures trade relatively flat following yesterday’s circa 3.7% gains. Downside was initially seen in the wake of last night’s unexpected build in the API inventories (+1.758mln vs. Exp. -0.200mln) with comments from the Iranian oil minster stating that USD 60/bbl is a good price for oil given current conditions with USD 70/bbl too high a level. Note, the comments appear to be at odds with reports yesterday suggesting that Saudi are to seek an oil price of around USD 80/bbl. However, losses were short-lived with traders mindful of any geopolitical developments with US military officials saying that the US is ready to attack Syria upon orders from President Trump which could come at any time. In metals markets, spot gold has benefitted from the modest risk aversion seen in markets thus far with the slightly softer USD also giving prices a helping hand. Elsewhere, copper was initially firmer overnight alongside early gains in Chinese metals amid restocking demand and expectations of increased construction activity in the upcoming month before staging a retreat. Finally, iron ore prices were seen lower overnight amid concerns over steel margins, whilst aluminium is once again seen higher in London trade as the fallout from Russian sanctions continues to guide price action.

Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih says happy with oil market at present. (Newswires)

Iran Oil Minister Zanganeh says current oil prices are acceptable and that all are comfortable with the price. (Newswires)

US API weekly crude stocks (6 Apr) +1.758M vs. Exp. -0.200M (Prev. -3.280M)

API Cushing number (6 Apr) +1.452M vs. Exp. 1.50M (Prev. 4.058M)

API weekly Distillate stocks (6 Apr) -3.849M vs. Exp. 2.200M (Prev. 2.200M)

API weekly Gasoline stocks (6 Apr) +2.005M vs. Exp. -1.400M (Prev. 1.123M)

The 10 year debt future is hovering just below the top of a relatively tight 122.31-37 range vs Tuesday’s 122.25 close.

Bunds: off to a flyer as geopolitical jitters drive safe-haven demand
content: Although US Treasuries are only moderately firmer, the core 10 year German benchmark has seen extended gains off the Eurex open to a 159.32 early high (+27 ticks) and appears to be factoring a risk-off premium pending a US-led response to the latest attacks in Syria. Some market participants may also be covering shorts made on the back of hawkish comments from ECB’s Nowotny on Tuesday that were subsequently confirmed as his own view and not necessarily consistent with the GC consensus. On that note, March policy meeting minutes could offer more insight along with anything divulged on the economy and guidance from Hansson and Draghi. On the flip-side, German long end supply and the 10 year UST auction may require some concession, and more immediately debt will be eyeing EU stocks for additional direction.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from Airbus, Novartis and Fiat Chrysler
content:
11th April 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets traded mixed as sentiment settled down from the bullishness seen from President Xi Jinping’s conciliatory tone on Tuesday which resulted to a solid performance on Wall St, while attention turned to the geopolitical climate with a possible announcement on Syria said to be imminent. ASX 200 (-0.3%) failed to sustain mild opening gains as softer Australian consumer sentiment data and weaker than expected Chinese inflation figures clouded the upside seen in commodity related sectors. Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) was also lacklustre with J Front the worst off amongst the retailers on expectations of weaker profits this year, while SoftBank outperformed on M&A hopes after reports its unit Sprint and T-Mobile renewed merger talks. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) were initially choppy as participants digested the miss on Chinese CPI and PPI data, although stocks gradually found some comfort from efforts by PBoC Governor Yi Gang to build upon the momentum from President Xi at the Boao forum in which the PBoC Governor talked about opening up and announced to increase stock connect quotas.

FTSE

Sky (SKY LN) – The offices of 21st Century Fox (FOX) have been raided by an investigation from the European Commission. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CENTRICA (CNA LN) DOWNGRADED TO REDUCE FROM HOLD AT HSBC

PREMIER OIL (PMO LN) RAISED FROM EQUAL WEIGHT TO UNDERWEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

DAX

Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) - Sprint (S) and T-Mobile (TMUS) have reportedly restarted deal talks, according to WSJ. This is of relevance to Deutsche Telekom whom own a 64% stake in T-Mobile. (WSJ)

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – Co. is said to raise production of the A320neo to 63 per month by Q2 2019 vs. current rate of 60 per month. (Newswires)

Air Liquide (AI FP) – The co. has signed a contract to start in H2 2018 and to end in 2021 with Lyondellbasell, becoming the oxygen supplier for the new largest plant of this kind. (Newswires)

OTHER COMPANIES

Suez Environment (SEV FP) – Co. are in discussions to acquire EDCO for EUR 200mln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

TOTAL (FP FP) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT DEUTSCHE BANK

REMY COINTREAU (RCO FP) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

PAN-EUROPE

Air France (AF FP) / Lufthansa (LHA GY) / easyJet (EZJ LN) – Alitalia have received offers from Air France (AF FP), Lufthansa (LHA GY) and easyJet (EZJ LN). Commissioners to evaluate offers in coming days. (Newswires)

ERG (ERG IM) – Unicredit (UCG IM) have completed the placement of ERG shares equal to ~4% of Erg’s capital at EUR 18.6/share so as to raise EUR 111.84mln. (Newswires)

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – Consob, the market regulator has confirmed that Elliott Advisers have 8.848% of Telecom Italia. (Newswires)

Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) – The car co. and the US Justice Department are in advanced stage talks for a diesel emissions settlement. (Newswires)

Airport Operators – The investment fund Global Infrastructure Partners is considering the sale of its 42% share in London’s Gatwick Airport. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ENI (ENI IM) RAISED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT DEUTSCHE BANK

SMI

Novartis (NOVN SW) – The co said its drug Afintor Disperz has received US approval for TSC-associated partial onset seizures. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

Sulzer (SUN SW) – The co have had their US bank accounts frozen after Viktor Vekelensberg appeared as a sanctioned person. (Newswires)

Clariant (CLN SW) – The co. has said that regional growth initiatives in China have a potential to double sales. (Newswires)

SCANDINAVIA

Nokia (NOKIA FH) – Alphabet (GOOGL) is in discussions to buy the co.’s broadband system which provides in-flight technology solutions. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

 

ASSA ABLOY (ASSAB SS) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT DEUTSCHE BANK 

NOKIA (NOKIA FH) INITIAITED WITH A BUY RATING AT BERENBERG

US

* EQUITIES: SPX +1.67% at 2657, NDX +2.2% at 6616, DJI +1.8% at 24409

* SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): +1.15%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): +0.53%, ENERGY (XLE): +3.42%, FINANCIALS (XLF): +1.28%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): +1.78%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): +1.66%, MATERIALS (XLB): +2.16%, TECH (XLK): +2.52%, TELECOMS (XTL): +2.32%, UTLITIES (XLU): -0.71%.

US Equity futures were buoyed by an improved risk sentiment following China President Xi’s speech overnight. There were some negative ticks in PM trade after an ECB spokesperson walked back from hawkish comments made earlier in the session by Nowotny, which saw Bunds bid, Treasuries rise in sympathy, putting pressure on the equity complex and seeing gains pared. However, while stocks were higher, futures were traversing sideways for much of the US session, with ES straddling 2650, only making moves above that area in late trade. In stock specifics, autos were bid after China’s Business Journal stated the country is considering cutting import duties on cars by half, with all major names closing green, led by Tesla (TSLA). M&A news today in pre-market saw Verifone (PAY) be acquired by Francisco Partners for $3.4bln which saw PAY rise over 51%. During trading hours WSJ reported Sprint (S) and T-Mobile (TMUS) started off deal talks again, which was followed by higher spikes in both companies, as well as AT&T (T), Time Warner (TWX) and Verizon (VZ), however cell tower stocks such as Crown Castle (CCI), SBA Communications (SBAC) and American Tower (AMT) spiked lower and closed the day in the red. In late trade, tech was in focus as Facebook’s (FB) CEO Zuckerberg testified to lawmakers; there was little by way of new information, though tech and FB itself had an upside bias.  Shares traded higher throughout most the testimony but came off highs as Zuckerberg stated there will always be a free version of Facebook.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian equity markets traded mixed as sentiment settled down from the bullishness seen yesterday
content:
• Asian equity markets traded mixed as sentiment settled down from the bullishness seen yesterday
  • ECB’s spokesperson said recent comments by ECB’s Nowotny are his own views and they do not represent the ECB’s governing council view
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK production figures, US CPI, DoEs, FOMC minutes, BoJ’s Kuroda, ECB’s Hansson and ECB’s Draghi

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed as sentiment settled down from the bullishness seen from President Xi Jinping’s conciliatory tone on Tuesday which resulted to a solid performance on Wall St, while attention turned to the geopolitical climate with a possible announcement on Syria said to be imminent. ASX 200 (-0.3%) failed to sustain mild opening gains as softer Australian consumer sentiment data and weaker than expected Chinese inflation figures clouded the upside seen in commodity related sectors. Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) was also lacklustre with J Front the worst off amongst the retailers on expectations of weaker profits this year, while SoftBank outperformed on M&A hopes after reports its unit Sprint and T-Mobile renewed merger talks. Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) were initially choppy as participants digested the miss on Chinese CPI and PPI data, although stocks gradually found some comfort from efforts by PBoC Governor Yi Gang to build upon the momentum from President Xi at the Boao forum in which the PBoC Governor talked about opening up and announced to increase stock connect quotas. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat as prices lacked direction amid an indecisive risk tone in the region, while the BoJ also kept the amounts of its Rinban announcement unchanged at just over JPY 1tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC Governor Yi Gang said China will implement financial market opening up steps and that China will remove foreign ownership caps on banks, while he added that trade between US and China should balance out in the future. Governor Yi further commented that China will not allow CNY to depreciate and will permit domestic and foreign financial companies to compete on an equal playing field. (Newswires)

PBoC Governor Yi Gang also announced to increase daily quota limits for the stock connect with Hong Kong and that China targets launching the Shanghai-London stock connect within this year, while the CSRC later stated that daily quotas for stock connect scheme are to be expanded as of May 1st. (Newswires)

China Vice Finance Minister said China will continue to announce more tax cuts and conduct personal income reforms, while the official added that China will implement tariff cuts ASAP and that the announcement to reduce tariffs was based on its own decision. (Newswires)

Chinese CPI (Mar) Y/Y 2.10% vs. Exp. 2.60% (Prev. 2.90%). (Newswires)
Chinese PPI (Mar) Y/Y 3.10% vs. Exp. 3.30% (Prev. 3.70%)

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.2911 (Prev. 6.3071)
UK/EU

ECB’s spokesperson said recent comments by ECB’s Nowotny are his own views and they do not represent the ECB’s governing council view. (Newswires)

FX

FX markets were relatively flat overnight in which most majors remained at levels seen during late US trade. This kept the DXY near 2-week lows, while EUR/USD held on to most the upside seen following previous hawkish comments from ECB’s Nowotny on rate hikes, which a central bank spokesperson later clarified was Nowotny’s own view and did not represent the ECB governing council. Elsewhere, USD/JPY was off best levels amid the indecisive risk tone, while commodity-linked currencies remained firm after the prior day’s advances which were aided by 3.7% gains in oil prices, although AUD/USD marginally pulled back following lacklustre data.

Australian Westpac Consumer Sentiment Index (Apr) 102.4 (Prev. 103.0). (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight with oil prices taking a breather following the prior day’s rally which was fuelled by risk sentiment and OPEC rhetoric including reports that Saudi is said to seek prices near USD 80/bbl. This eventually resulted to 3.7% gains in WTI on Tuesday and supported Brent to its highest since December 2014, although prices have pulled back from best levels on mild profit taking and after a surprise build in API crude inventories. Elsewhere, copper was initially firmer alongside early gains in Chinese metals trade amid restocking demand amid expectations of increased construction activity in the upcoming months, before prices gradually retreated, and gold prices remained afloat as the DXY languished.

US API weekly crude stocks (6 Apr) +1.758M vs. Exp. -0.200M (Prev. -3.280M). (Newswires)

EIA raised 2018 & 2019 world oil demand growth forecasts, while it cut view on 2018 production but raised view on 2019 production. (Newswires)

Saudi Energy Ministry said Saudi Arabia plans to keep crude oil exports below 7.0mln bpd for May and that it sees Saudi Arabia’s March crude production at 9.91mln bpd. Furthermore, the ministry reiterated its commitment to restore inventories to their normal levels and there were also comments from Energy Minister Al-Falih that he is happy with the oil market at present. (Newswires)

UAE Energy Minister said long-term ties with Russia will allow OPEC to react more effectively in changing oil markets fundamentals, while reports added that it is too early for OPEC to discuss oil cut extension or replacing falling Venezuela output. (PlattsOil)

Iran Oil Minister Zanganeh said current oil prices are acceptable and that all are comfortable with the price. (Newswires)

Canada’s Energy Minister said the government is fully supportive of the Kinder Morgan Pipeline and that it is not a matter of whether it will go ahead but rather how it will proceed. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

US military officials said the US ready to attack Syria upon order from Trump which could come at any time, while there were also separate reports that the announcement on US action in Syria was said to be imminent. (i24 News/Fox)

US-led coalition reportedly asked all Middle East flight companies to change itineraries for the next 48 hours amid a possible strike. (Kurdistan24)

Russia vetoed US bid at UN Security Council to present a new inquiry to lay blame for chemical weapons over the attacks in Syria, while there were also reports that Russia is jamming US drones over Syria airspace impacting military ops. (Newswires)

US

Bear-flattening was the theme, with short-end yields higher by around 3bps, while the longer-end of the curve was more or less unchanged at settlement. President Xi’s speech overnight was the catalyst, helping to drive decent overnight volumes. However, as we entered the European day, the tplex was happy to range trade, with 10-year T-Notes patrolling the 120-24 to 120-29 bracket. There was some attention on the 5s30s part of the curve, which flattened to the narrowest since 2007. In the late part of the European afternoon, Treasuries were for a short while dictated by Bund action, which caught a bid after the ECB backtracked from Nowotny’s hawkish comments, made earlier in the day. However, the effect was short lived. The US sold $30bln of 3yr notes, which tailed by 0.1bps, with the yield the highest at auction since May 2007. Cover was more-or-less in line with recent averages, though indirect participation dropped to the lowest since September; dealers took the most since September 2017. This week’s $64bln of 3s/10s/30s will see a net paydown of around $12.5bln by the US Treasury, given the $74.5bln of maturities at the mid-month settlement. US 10y T-notes futs settled down 4+ ticks at 120-24+.

White House said it sees encouragement in Chinese President Xi’s words but added it wants to see concrete actions. (Newswires)

content:

Asia equity markets are mixed as sentiment settles down from the bullishness seen from President Xi Jinping’s conciliatory tone on Tuesday which resulted to a solid performance on Wall St, while attention turns to the geopolitical climate with a possible announcement on Syria said to be imminent. ASX 200 (-0.3%) failed to sustain mild opening gains as softer Australian consumer sentiment data and weaker than expected Chinese inflation figures dampen the upside seen in commodity related sectors. Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) is also lacklustre with J Front the worst off amongst the retailers on expectations of weaker profits this year, while SoftBank outperforms on M&A hopes after reports its unit Sprint and T-Mobile renewed merger talks. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) are choppy as participants digest the miss on Chinese CPI and PPI data, while the region is also seeing some fatigue with efforts by PBoC Governor Yi Gang to build upon the momentum from President Xi at the Boao forum, getting a milder reception.

FX markets are relatively flat overnight with most majors remaining at levels seen during late US trade. This has kept the DXY near 2-week lows, while EUR/USD holds on to most of the upside seen following previous hawkish comments from ECB’s Nowotny on rate hikes, which a central bank spokesperson later clarified was Nowotny’s own view and did not represent the ECB governing council. Elsewhere, USD/JPY is off best levels amid the indecisive risk tone, while commodity-linked currencies remain firm after the prior day’s advance which was aided by 3.7% gains in oil prices, although AUD/USD has marginally pulled back following lacklustre data.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat with prices lacking direction amid an indecisive risk tone in the region, while the BoJ also maintained the amounts unchanged in its Rinban announcement for just over JPY 1tln of JGBs in 1yr-10yr maturities.
